Title : The Lion , the Witch and the Wardrobe . A Story for [Children]117-children . [Author]118-author : [Lewis]32-lewis , C. S. [ [Clive Staples]33-clive staples ] ( 1898 - 1963 ) Date of first publication : 1950 Edition used as base for this ebook : [New York]2-new york : Macmillan , undated [ twenty - first printing ] Date first posted : 26 January 2014 Date last updated : 29 July 2019 Faded Page eBook # 201410B2

This eBook was produced by Al Haines

[ Transcriber 's note : Because of copyright considerations , the illustrations by [Pauline Baynes]34-pauline baynes ( 1922 - 2008 ) have been omitted from this etext . ]

THE LION , THE WITCH

_ and _

THE WARDROBE

_ A Story for [Children]117-children _

BY C. S. LEWIS

_ To [Lucy Barfield]60-lucy _

_ [My]0-i dear [Lucy]60-lucy , _

_ [I]0-i wrote this story for [you]60-lucy , but when [I]0-i began it [I]0-i had not realized that [girls]120-girls grow quicker than books . As a result [you]60-lucy are already too old for fairy tales , and by the time it is printed and bound [you]60-lucy will be older still . But some day [you]60-lucy will be old enough to start reading fairy tales again . [You]60-lucy can then take it down from some upper shelf , dust it , and tell [me]0-i what [you]60-lucy think of it . [I]0-i shall probably be too deaf to hear , and too old to understand a word [you]60-lucy say , but [I]0-i shall still be _

_ [your]60-lucy affectionate Godfather , _ _ C. S. Lewis _

CONTENTS

I. _ [Lucy]60-lucy Looks into a Wardrobe _ II . _ What [Lucy]60-lucy Found There _ III . _ [Edmund]36-edmund and the Wardrobe _ IV . _ Turkish Delight _ V. _ Back on [This Side of the Door _ VI]121-this side of the door _ vi . _ Into [the Forest]3-the forest _ VII . _ A Day with [the Beavers _ VIII]37-the beavers . _ What Happened after Dinner _ IX . _ In [the Witch 's House]4-the witch 's house _ X. _ The Spell Begins to Break _ XI . _ [Aslan]72-aslan Is Nearer _ XII . _ [Peter]38-peter 's First Battle _ XIII . _ Deep Magic from the Dawn of Time _ XIV . _ The Triumph of the Witch _ XV . _ Deeper Magic from _ before _ the Dawn of Time _ XVI . _ What Happened about [the Statues _ XVII]39-the statues _ xvii . _ The Hunting of the White Stag _

CHAPTER I

_ [Lucy]60-lucy Looks into a Wardrobe _

Once there were [four children]122-four children whose names were [Peter]38-peter , [Susan]40-susan , [Edmund]36-edmund and [Lucy]60-lucy . This story is about something that happened to [them]122-four children when [they]122-four children were sent away from [London]6-london during the war because of the air - raids . [They]122-four children were sent to [the house of]123-the house of [an old Professor who lived in [the heart of [the country]126-the country]125-the heart of the country , ten miles from [the nearest railway station]127-the nearest railway station and two miles from [the nearest post office]128-the nearest post office]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office . [He]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office had [no wife]129-no wife and [he]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office lived in [a very large house]130-a very large house with [a housekeeper called [Mrs. Macready]41-mrs. macready and [three servants]132-three servants]131-a housekeeper called mrs. macready and three servants . ( [Their]122-four children names were [Ivy]42-ivy , [Margaret]43-margaret and [Betty]44-betty , but [they]122-four children do not come into the story much . ) [He]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office [himself]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office was [a very old man with shaggy white hair]133-a very old man with shaggy white hair , which grew over most of [his]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office face as well as on [his]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office head , and [they]122-four children liked [him]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office almost at once ; but on the first evening when [he]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office came out to meet [them]122-four children at the front door [he]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office was so odd - looking that [Lucy]60-lucy ( who was [the youngest]134-the youngest ) was a little afraid of [him]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office , and [Edmund]36-edmund ( who was [the next youngest]135-the next youngest ) wanted to laugh and had to keep on pretending [he]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office was blowing [his]124-an old professor who lived in the heart of the country , ten miles from the nearest railway station and two miles from the nearest post office nose to hide it .

As soon as [they]122-four children had said good night to [the Professor]136-the professor and gone [upstairs]137-upstairs on the first night , [the boys]138-the boys came into [[the girls]139-the girls ' room]140-the girls ' room and [they]138-the boys all talked it over .

" [We]122-four children 've fallen on [our]122-four children feet and no mistake , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter . " This is going to be perfectly splendid . [That old chap]1216-that old chap will let [us]122-four children do anything [we]122-four children like . "[38-peter]

" [I]40-susan think [he]1216-that old chap 's [an old dear]1217-an old dear , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan .

" Oh , come off it ! "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , who was tired and pretending not to be tired , which always made [him]36-edmund bad - tempered . " Do n't go on talking like that . "[36-edmund]

" Like what ? "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan ; " and anyway , it 's time [you]36-edmund were in bed . "[40-susan]

" Trying to talk like [Mother]1218-mother , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund . " And who are [you]60-lucy to say when [I]36-edmund 'm to go to bed ? Go to bed [yourself]60-lucy . "[36-edmund]

" Had n't [we]122-four children all better go to bed ? "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy . " There 's sure to be a row if [we]122-four children 're heard talking [here]1219-here . "[60-lucy]

" No there wo n't , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter . " [I]38-peter tell [you]60-lucy this is [the sort of house where [no one]1221-no one 's going to mind what [we]122-four children do]1220-the sort of house where no one 's going to mind what we do . Anyway , [they]1222-they wo n't hear [us]122-four children . It 's about ten minutes ' walk from here down to [that dining room]1223-that dining room , and any amount of stairs and passages in between . "[38-peter]

" What 's that noise ? "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy suddenly . It was [a far larger house than [she]60-lucy had ever been in before and the thought of all those long passages and rows of doors leading into [empty rooms]142-empty rooms]141-a far larger house than she had ever been in before and the thought of all those long passages and rows of doors leading into empty rooms was beginning to make [her]60-lucy feel a little creepy .

" It 's only a bird , silly , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund .

" It 's an owl , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter . " This is going to be a wonderful place for birds . [I]38-peter shall go to bed now . [I]38-peter say , let 's go and explore to - morrow . [You]60-lucy might find anything in [a place like this]1224-a place like this . Did [you]60-lucy see [those mountains]1225-those mountains as [we]1226-we came along ? And [the woods]1227-the woods ? There might be eagles . There might be stags . There 'll be hawks . "[38-peter]

" Badgers ! "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy .

" [Snakes]45-snakes ! "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund .

" [Foxes]46-foxes ! "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan .

But when next morning came , there was a steady rain falling , so thick that when [you]143-you looked out of the window [you]143-you could see neither [the mountains]144-the mountains nor [the woods]1227-the woods nor even [the stream]146-the stream in [the garden]147-the garden .

" Of course it _ would _ be raining ! "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund . [They]148-they had just finished breakfast with [the Professor]136-the professor and were [upstairs]137-upstairs in [the room [he]136-the professor had set apart for [them]148-they]151-the room he had set apart for them -- [a long , low room with two windows looking out in one direction and two in another]152-a long , low room with two windows looking out in one direction and two in another .

" Do stop grumbling , [Ed]36-edmund , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan . " Ten to one it 'll clear up in an hour or so . And in the meantime [we]148-they 're pretty well off . There 's a wireless and lots of books . "[40-susan]

" Not for [me]38-peter , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter , " [I]38-peter 'm going to explore in [the house]1228-the house . "[38-peter]

[Everyone]153-everyone agreed to this and that was how the adventures began . It was [the sort of house that [you]155-you never seem to come to the end of]154-the sort of house that you never seem to come to the end of , and [it]154-the sort of house that you never seem to come to the end of was full of unexpected places . The first few doors [they]148-they tried led only into [spare bedrooms]156-spare bedrooms , as [everyone]153-everyone had expected that [they]148-they would ; but soon [they]148-they came to [a very long room full of pictures]158-a very long room full of pictures and there [they]148-they found a suit of armour ; and after that was [a room all hung with green , with a harp in one corner]159-a room all hung with green , with a harp in one corner ; and then came three steps down and five steps up , and then a kind of little [upstairs hall]160-upstairs hall and a door that led out onto [a balcony]161-a balcony , and then a whole series of rooms that led into [each other]162-each other and were lined with books -- most of them very old books and some bigger than a Bible in [a church]163-a church . And shortly after that [they]148-they looked into [a room]164-a room that was quite empty except for one big wardrobe ; the sort that has a looking - glass in the door . There was nothing else in [the room]165-the room at all except a dead blue - bottle on the window - sill .

" Nothing there ! "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter , and [they]148-they all trooped out again -- all except [Lucy]60-lucy . [She]60-lucy stayed behind because [she]60-lucy thought it would be worth while trying the door of [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe , even though [she]60-lucy felt almost sure that it would be locked . To [her]60-lucy surprise it opened quite easily , and two moth - balls dropped out .

Looking into the inside , [she]60-lucy saw several coats hanging up -- mostly long fur coats . There was nothing [Lucy]60-lucy liked so much as the smell and feel of fur . [She]60-lucy immediately stepped into [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe and got in among the coats and rubbed [her]60-lucy face against them , leaving the door open , of course , because [she]60-lucy knew that it is very foolish to shut [oneself]168-oneself into any wardrobe . Soon [she]60-lucy went further in and found that there was a second row of coats hanging up behind [the first one]169-the first one . It was almost quite dark in there and [she]60-lucy kept [her]60-lucy arms stretched out in front of [her]60-lucy so as not to bump [her]60-lucy face into the back of [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe . [She]60-lucy took a step further in -- then two or three steps -- always expecting to feel woodwork against the tips of [her]60-lucy fingers . But [she]60-lucy could not feel it .

" This must be a simply enormous wardrobe ! "[60-lucy] thought [Lucy]60-lucy , going still further in and pushing the soft folds of the coats aside to make room for [her]60-lucy . Then [she]60-lucy noticed that there was something crunching under [her]60-lucy feet . " [I]60-lucy wonder is that more moth - balls ? "[60-lucy] [she]60-lucy thought , stooping down to feel it with [her]60-lucy hands . But instead of feeling the hard , smooth wood of the floor of [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe , [she]60-lucy felt something soft and powdery and extremely cold , " This is very queer , "[60-lucy] [she]60-lucy said , and went on a step or two further .

Next moment [she]60-lucy found that what was rubbing against [her]60-lucy face and hands was no longer soft fur but something hard and rough and even prickly . " Why , it is just like branches of trees ! "[60-lucy] exclaimed [Lucy]60-lucy . And then [she]60-lucy saw that there was a light ahead of [her]60-lucy ; not a few inches away where the back of [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe ought to have been , but a long way off . Something cold and soft was falling on [her]60-lucy . A moment later [she]60-lucy found that [she]60-lucy was standing in the middle of a wood at night - time with snow under [her]60-lucy feet and snowflakes falling through the air .

[Lucy]60-lucy felt a little frightened , but [she]60-lucy felt very inquisitive and excited as well . [She]60-lucy looked back over [her]60-lucy shoulder and there , between the dark tree - trunks , [she]60-lucy could still see the open doorway of [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe and even catch a glimpse of [the empty room from which [she]60-lucy had set out]174-the empty room from which she had set out . ( [She]60-lucy had , of course , left the door open , for [she]60-lucy knew that it is a very silly thing to shut oneself into [a wardrobe]175-a wardrobe . ) It seemed to be still daylight there . " [I]60-lucy can always get back if anything goes wrong , "[60-lucy] thought [Lucy]60-lucy . [She]60-lucy began to walk forward , _ crunch - crunch _ , over the snow and through the wood towards the other light .

In about ten minutes [she]60-lucy reached it and found that it was a lamp - post . As [she]60-lucy stood looking at it , wondering why there was a lamp - post in the middle of a wood and wondering what to do next , [she]60-lucy heard a pitter patter of feet coming towards [her]60-lucy . And soon after that [a very strange person]176-a very strange person stepped out from among the trees into the light of the lamp - post .

[He]176-a very strange person was only a little taller than [Lucy]60-lucy [herself]60-lucy and [he]176-a very strange person carried over [his]176-a very strange person head an umbrella , white with snow . From the waist upwards [he]176-a very strange person was like [a man]177-a man , but [his]176-a very strange person legs were shaped like a goat 's ( the hair on them was glossy black ) and instead of feet [he]176-a very strange person had goat 's hoofs . [He]176-a very strange person also had a tail , but [Lucy]60-lucy did not notice this at first because it was neatly caught up over the arm that held the umbrella so as to keep it from trailing in the snow . [He]176-a very strange person had a red woollen muffler round [his]176-a very strange person neck and [his]176-a very strange person skin was rather reddish too . [He]176-a very strange person had a strange , but pleasant little face with a short pointed beard and curly hair , and out of the hair there stuck two horns , one on each side of [his]176-a very strange person forehead . One of [his]176-a very strange person hands , as [I]0-i have said , held the umbrella : in the other arm [he]176-a very strange person carried several brown paper parcels . What with the parcels and the snow it looked just as if [he]176-a very strange person had been doing [his]176-a very strange person Christmas shopping . [He]176-a very strange person was [a Faun]178-a faun . And when [he]176-a very strange person saw [Lucy]60-lucy [he]176-a very strange person gave such a start of surprise that [he]176-a very strange person dropped all [his]176-a very strange person parcels .

" Goodness gracious [me]179-the faun ! "[179-the faun] exclaimed [the Faun]179-the faun .

CHAPTER II

_ What [Lucy]60-lucy Found There _

" Good evening , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy . But [the Faun]179-the faun was so busy picking up [his]179-the faun parcels that at first [he]179-the faun did not reply . When [he]179-the faun had finished [he]179-the faun made [her]60-lucy a little bow .

" Good evening , good evening , "[47-the faun] said [the Faun]47-the faun . " Excuse [me]47-the faun -- [I]47-the faun do n't want to be inquisitive -- but should [I]47-the faun be right in thinking that [you]60-lucy are [a Daughter of [Eve]48-adam]1229-a daughter of eve ? "[47-the faun]

" [My]60-lucy name 's [Lucy]60-lucy , "[60-lucy] said [she]60-lucy , not quite understanding [him]179-the faun .

" But [you]60-lucy are -- forgive [me]179-the faun -- [you]60-lucy are what [they]1230-they call [a girl]1231-a girl ? "[179-the faun] asked [the Faun]179-the faun .

" Of course [I]60-lucy 'm [a girl]1231-a girl , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy .

" [You]47-the faun are in fact [Human]1233-human ? "[47-the faun]

" Of course [I]60-lucy 'm human , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy , still a little puzzled .

" To be sure , to be sure , "[47-the faun] said [the Faun]47-the faun . " How stupid of [me]47-the faun ! But [I]47-the faun 've never seen [a Son of [Adam]48-adam]1234-a son of adam or [a Daughter of Eve]1229-a daughter of eve before . [I]47-the faun am delighted . That is to say-- "[47-the faun] and then [he]47-the faun stopped as if [he]47-the faun had been going to say something [he]47-the faun had not intended but had remembered in time . " Delighted , delighted , "[47-the faun] [he]47-the faun went on . " Allow [me]47-the faun to introduce [myself]47-the faun . [My]47-the faun name is [Tumnus]47-the faun . "[47-the faun]

" [I]60-lucy am very pleased to meet [you]47-the faun , [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy .

" And may [I]49-mr. tumnus ask , [O Lucy]60-lucy , [Daughter of Eve]1236-daughter of eve , "[49-mr. tumnus] said [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus , " how [you]60-lucy have come into [Narnia]7-narnia ? "[49-mr. tumnus]

" [Narnia]7-narnia ? What 's that ? "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy .

" This is [the land of [Narnia]7-narnia]1237-the land of narnia , "[179-the faun] said [the Faun]179-the faun , " where [we]1238-we are now ; all that lies between the lamp - post and [the great castle of [Cair Paravel]8-cair paravel on [the eastern sea]1240-the eastern sea]1239-the great castle of cair paravel on the eastern sea . And [you]60-lucy -- [you]60-lucy have come from [the wild woods of the west]1241-the wild woods of the west ? "[179-the faun]

" [I]60-lucy -- [I]60-lucy got in through the wardrobe in [the spare room]1242-the spare room , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy .

" Ah ! "[49-mr. tumnus] said [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus in a rather melancholy voice , " if only [I]49-mr. tumnus had worked harder at geography when [I]49-mr. tumnus was [a little Faun]1243-a little faun , [I]49-mr. tumnus should no doubt know all about [those strange countries]1244-those strange countries . It is too late now . "[49-mr. tumnus]

" But [they]1244-those strange countries are n't countries at all , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy , almost laughing . " It 's only just back there -- at least -- [I'm]60-lucy not sure . It is summer there . "[60-lucy]

" Meanwhile , "[49-mr. tumnus] said [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus , " it is winter in [Narnia]7-narnia , and has been for ever so long , and [we]1245-we shall both catch cold if [we]1245-we stand here talking in the snow . [Daughter of [Eve]48-adam from [the far land of Spare Oom where eternal summer reigns]1247-the far land of spare oom where eternal summer reigns around [the bright city of War Drobe]1248-the bright city of war drobe]1246-daughter of eve from the far land of spare oom where eternal summer reigns around the bright city of war drobe , how would it be if [you]60-lucy came and had tea with [me]49-mr. tumnus ? "[49-mr. tumnus]

" Thank [you]49-mr. tumnus very much , [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy . " But [I]60-lucy was wondering whether [I]60-lucy ought to be getting back . "[60-lucy]

" It 's only just round the corner , "[179-the faun] said [the Faun]179-the faun , " and there 'll be a roaring fire -- and toast -- and sardines -- and cake . "[179-the faun]

" Well , it 's very kind of [you]49-mr. tumnus , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy . " But [I]60-lucy sha n't be able to stay long . "[60-lucy]

" If [you]60-lucy will take [my]49-mr. tumnus arm , [Daughter of Eve]48-adam , "[49-mr. tumnus] said [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus , " [I]49-mr. tumnus shall be able to hold the umbrella over both of [us]185-they . That 's the way . Now -- off [we]185-they go . "[49-mr. tumnus]

And so [Lucy]60-lucy found [herself]60-lucy walking through the wood arm in arm with [this strange creature]184-this strange creature as if [they]185-they had known [one another]186-one another all [their]185-they lives .

[They]185-they had not gone far before [they]185-they came to a place where [the ground]187-the ground became rough and there were rocks all about and little hills up and [little hills down]188-little hills down . At [the bottom of [one small valley]190-one small valley]189-the bottom of one small valley [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus turned suddenly aside as if [he]49-mr. tumnus were going to walk straight into [an unusually large rock]191-an unusually large rock , but at the last moment [Lucy]60-lucy found [he]49-mr. tumnus was leading [her]60-lucy into the entrance of [a cave]192-a cave . As soon as [they]185-they were inside [she]60-lucy found [herself]60-lucy blinking in the light of a wood fire . Then [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus stooped and took a flaming piece of wood out of the fire with a neat little pair of tongs , and lit a lamp . " Now [we]185-they sha n't be long , "[49-mr. tumnus] [he]49-mr. tumnus said , and immediately put a kettle on .

[Lucy]60-lucy thought [she]60-lucy had never been in [a nicer place]193-a nicer place . [It]192-a cave was [a little , dry , clean cave of reddish stone with a carpet on the floor and two little chairs]194-a little , dry , clean cave of reddish stone with a carpet on the floor and two little chairs ( " one for [me]49-mr. tumnus and one for [a friend]1249-a friend , "[49-mr. tumnus] said [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus ) and a table and a dresser and a mantelpiece over the fire and above that a picture of [an old Faun with a grey beard]195-an old faun with a grey beard . [Lucy]60-lucy looked at these while [he]49-mr. tumnus was setting out the tea things . They had titles like _ The Life and Letters of [Silenus _ or _ Nymphs]197-silenus _ or _ nymphs and [Their]198-their Ways _ or _ Men , [Monks]199-monks and [Gamekeepers]200-gamekeepers ; a Study in Popular Legend _ or _ Is Man a Myth _ ?

" Now , [Daughter of Eve]48-adam ! "[47-the faun] said [the Faun]47-the faun .

And really it was a wonderful tea . There was a nice brown egg , lightly boiled , for each of [them]201-them , and then sardines on toast , and then buttered toast , and then toast with honey , and then a sugar - topped cake . And when [Lucy]60-lucy was tired of eating [the Faun]47-the faun began to talk . [He]49-mr. tumnus had wonderful tales to tell of life in [the forest]202-the forest . [He]49-mr. tumnus told about the midnight dances and how [the Nymphs who lived in [the wells]204-the wells]203-the nymphs who lived in the wells and [the Dryads who lived in the trees]205-the dryads who lived in the trees came out to dance with [the Fauns]50-the fauns ; about long hunting parties after [the milk - white Stag who could give [you]207-you wishes if [you]207-you caught [him]47-the faun]206-the milk - white stag who could give you wishes if you caught him ; about feasting and treasure - seeking with the wild Red Dwarfs in [deep mines]208-deep mines and [caverns far beneath [the forest floor]210-the forest floor]209-caverns far beneath the forest floor ; and then about summer when [the woods]1227-the woods were green and [old Silenus]51-old silenus on [his]49-mr. tumnus fat donkey would come to visit [them]1227-the woods , and sometimes [Bacchus]52-bacchus [himself]52-bacchus , and then [the streams]212-the streams would run with wine instead of water and [the whole forest]213-the whole forest would give itself up to jollification for weeks on end . " Not that it is n't always winter now , "[49-mr. tumnus] [he]49-mr. tumnus added gloomily . Then to cheer [himself]49-mr. tumnus up [he]49-mr. tumnus took out from its case on the dresser a strange little flute that looked as if it were made of straw and began to play . And the tune [he]49-mr. tumnus played made [Lucy]60-lucy want to cry and laugh and dance and go to sleep all at the same time . It must have been hours later when [she]60-lucy shook [herself]60-lucy and said ,

" Oh [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus -- [I'm]60-lucy so sorry to stop [you]49-mr. tumnus , and [I]60-lucy do love that tune -- but really , [I]60-lucy must go [home]1250-home . [I]60-lucy only meant to stay for a few minutes . "[60-lucy]

" It 's no good _ now _ , [you]60-lucy know , "[179-the faun] said [the Faun]179-the faun , laying down [his]179-the faun flute and shaking [his]179-the faun head at [her]60-lucy very sorrowfully .

" No good ? "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy , jumping up and feeling rather frightened . " What do [you]49-mr. tumnus mean ? [I]60-lucy 've got to go [home]1250-home at once . [The others]1252-the others will be wondering what has happened to [me]60-lucy . "[60-lucy] But a moment later [she]60-lucy asked , " [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus ! Whatever is the matter ? "[60-lucy] for [the Faun]47-the faun 's brown eyes had filled with tears and then the tears began trickling down [his]47-the faun cheeks , and soon they were running off the end of [his]47-the faun nose ; and at last [he]47-the faun covered [his]47-the faun face with [his]47-the faun hands and began to howl .

" [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus ! [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus ! "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy in great distress . " Do n't ! Do n't ! What is the matter ? Are n't [you]49-mr. tumnus well ? [Dear Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus , do tell [me]60-lucy what is wrong . "[60-lucy] But [the Faun]47-the faun continued sobbing as if [his]47-the faun heart would break . And even when [Lucy]60-lucy went over and put [her]60-lucy arms round [him]47-the faun and lent [him]47-the faun [her]60-lucy handkerchief , [he]47-the faun did not stop . [He]47-the faun merely took the handkerchief and kept on using it , wringing it out with both hands whenever it got too wet to be any more use , so that presently [Lucy]60-lucy was standing in a damp patch .

" [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus ! "[60-lucy] bawled [Lucy]60-lucy in [his]47-the faun ear , shaking [him]47-the faun . " Do stop . Stop it at once ! [You]47-the faun ought to be ashamed of [yourself]47-the faun , [a great big Faun like [you]47-the faun]1253-a great big faun like you . What on earth are [you]47-the faun crying about ? "[60-lucy]

" But what have [you]47-the faun done ? "[60-lucy] asked [Lucy]60-lucy .

" [The White Witch]1261-the white witch ? Who is [she]1261-the white witch ? "[49-mr. tumnus]

" [We]1281-we must go as quietly as [we]1281-we can , "[49-mr. tumnus] said [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus . " [The whole wood]1282-the whole wood is full of _ [[her]1283-her _ spies]1284-her _ spies . Even some of the trees are on [her]1283-her side . "[49-mr. tumnus]

[They]216-they both got up and left the tea things on the table , and [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus once more put up [his]49-mr. tumnus umbrella and gave [Lucy]60-lucy [his]49-mr. tumnus arm , and [they]216-they went out into the snow . The journey back was not at all like the journey to [[the Faun]47-the faun 's cave]217-the faun 's cave ; [they]216-they stole along as quickly as [they]216-they could , without speaking a word , and [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus kept to [the darkest places]218-the darkest places . [Lucy]60-lucy was relieved when [they]216-they reached the lamp - post again .

" Do [you]60-lucy know [your]60-lucy way from here , [Daughter of [Eve]48-adam]1236-daughter of eve ? "[49-mr. tumnus] said [Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus .

[Lucy]60-lucy looked very hard between the trees and could just see in the distance a patch of light that looked like daylight . " Yes , "[60-lucy] [she]60-lucy said , " [I]60-lucy can see the wardrobe door . "[60-lucy]

" Then be off [home]1250-home as quick as [you]60-lucy can , "[179-the faun] said [the Faun]179-the faun , " and -- c - can [you]60-lucy ever forgive [me]179-the faun for what [I]179-the faun meant to do ? "[179-the faun]

" Why , of course [I]60-lucy can , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy , shaking [him]49-mr. tumnus heartily by the hand . " And [I]60-lucy do hope [you]49-mr. tumnus wo n't get into dreadful trouble on [my]60-lucy account . "[60-lucy]

" [Farewell]54-farewell , [Daughter of [Eve]48-adam]1236-daughter of eve , "[49-mr. tumnus] said [he]49-mr. tumnus . " Perhaps [I]49-mr. tumnus may keep the handkerchief ? "[49-mr. tumnus]

" Rather ! "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy , and then ran towards [the far - off patch of daylight]220-the far - off patch of daylight as quickly as [her]60-lucy legs would carry [her]60-lucy . And presently instead of rough branches brushing past [her]60-lucy [she]60-lucy felt coats , and instead of crunching snow under [her]60-lucy feet [she]60-lucy felt wooden boards , and all at once [she]60-lucy found [herself]60-lucy jumping out of the wardrobe into [the same empty room from which the whole adventure had started]221-the same empty room from which the whole adventure had started . [She]60-lucy shut the wardrobe door tightly behind [her]60-lucy and looked around , panting for breath . It was still raining and [she]60-lucy could hear the voices of [the others]1252-the others in [the passage]223-the passage .

" [I]60-lucy 'm here , "[60-lucy] [she]60-lucy shouted . " [I]60-lucy 'm here . [I]60-lucy 've come back , [I]60-lucy 'm all right . "[60-lucy]

CHAPTER III

_ [Edmund]36-edmund and the Wardrobe _

[Lucy]60-lucy ran out of [the empty room]224-the empty room into [the passage]223-the passage and found [the other three]226-the other three .

" It 's all right , "[60-lucy] [she]60-lucy repeated , " [I]60-lucy 've come back . "[60-lucy]

" What on earth are [you]60-lucy talking about , [Lucy]60-lucy ? "[40-susan] asked [Susan]40-susan .

" Why ? "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy in amazement , " have n't [you]226-the other three all been wondering where [I]60-lucy was ? "[60-lucy]

" So [you]60-lucy 've been hiding , have [you]60-lucy ? "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter . " [Poor old Lu]60-lucy , hiding and [nobody]1288-nobody noticed ! [You]60-lucy 'll have to hide longer than that if [you]60-lucy want [people]1289-people to start looking for [you]60-lucy . "[38-peter]

" But [I]60-lucy 've been away for hours and hours , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy .

[The others]1252-the others all stared at [one another]186-one another .

" [Batty]55-batty ! "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund tapping [his]36-edmund head . " Quite batty . "[36-edmund]

" What do [you]60-lucy mean , [Lu]60-lucy ? "[38-peter] asked [Peter]38-peter .

" What [I]60-lucy said , "[60-lucy] answered [Lucy]60-lucy . " It was just after breakfast when [I]60-lucy went into [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe , and [I]60-lucy 've been away for hours and hours , and had tea , and all sorts of things have happened . "[60-lucy]

" Do n't be silly , [Lucy]60-lucy , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan . " [We]1291-we 've only just come out of [that room]1292-that room a moment ago , and [you]60-lucy were there then . "[40-susan]

" [She]60-lucy 's not being silly at all , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter , " [she]60-lucy 's just making up a story for fun , are n't [you]60-lucy , [Lu]60-lucy ? And why should n't [she]60-lucy ? "[38-peter]

" No , [Peter]38-peter , [I]60-lucy 'm not , "[60-lucy] [she]60-lucy said . " It's -- it 's [a magic wardrobe]1293-a magic wardrobe . There 's a wood inside [it]1293-a magic wardrobe , and it 's snowing , and there 's [a Faun]178-a faun and [a witch]1295-a witch and it 's called [Narnia]7-narnia ; come and see . "[60-lucy]

[The others]1252-the others did not know what to think , but [Lucy]60-lucy was so excited that [they]1252-the others all went back with [her]60-lucy into [the room]165-the room . [She]60-lucy rushed ahead of [them]1252-the others , flung open the door of [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe and cried , " Now ! go in and see for [yourselves]1252-the others . "[60-lucy]

" Why , [you]1252-the others goose , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan , putting [her]40-susan head inside and pulling the fur coats apart , " it 's just an ordinary wardrobe , look ! there 's the back of it . "[40-susan]

Then [everyone]153-everyone looked in and pulled the coats apart ; and [they]1252-the others all saw -- [Lucy]60-lucy [herself]60-lucy saw -- a perfectly ordinary wardrobe . There was no wood and no snow , only the back of the wardrobe , with hooks on it . [Peter]38-peter went in and rapped [his]38-peter knuckles on it to make sure that it was solid .

" A jolly good hoax , [Lu]60-lucy , "[38-peter] [he]38-peter said as [he]38-peter came out again , " [you]60-lucy have really taken [us]1252-the others in , [I]38-peter must admit . [We]1252-the others half believed [you]60-lucy . "[38-peter]

" But it was n't a hoax at all , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy , " really and truly . It was all different a moment ago . Honestly it was . [I]60-lucy promise . "[60-lucy]

" Come , [Lu]60-lucy , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter , " that 's going a bit far . [You]60-lucy 've had [your]60-lucy joke . Had n't [you]60-lucy better drop it now ? "[38-peter]

[Lucy]60-lucy grew very red in the face and tried to say something , though [she]60-lucy hardly knew what [she]60-lucy was trying to say , and burst into tears .

For the next few days [she]60-lucy was very miserable . [She]60-lucy could have made it up with [the others]1252-the others quite easily at any moment if [she]60-lucy could have brought [herself]60-lucy to say that the whole thing was only a story made up for fun . But [Lucy]60-lucy was [a very truthful girl]234-a very truthful girl and [she]60-lucy knew that [she]60-lucy was really in the right ; and [she]60-lucy could not bring [herself]60-lucy to say this . The others who thought [she]60-lucy was telling a lie , and a silly lie too , made [her]60-lucy very unhappy . [The two elder ones]235-the two elder ones did this without meaning to do it , but [Edmund]36-edmund could be spiteful , and on this occasion [he]36-edmund was spiteful . [He]36-edmund sneered and jeered at [Lucy]60-lucy and kept on asking [her]60-lucy if [she]60-lucy 'd found any other new countries in other cupboards all over [the house]1228-the house . What made it worse was that these days ought to have been delightful . The weather was fine and [they]237-they were out of doors from morning to night , bathing , fishing , climbing trees , birds ' nesting , and lying in the heather . But [Lucy]60-lucy could not properly enjoy any of it . And so things went on until the next wet day .

That day , when it came to the afternoon and there was still no sign of a break in the weather , [they]237-they decided to play hide - and - seek . [Susan]40-susan was " It "[40-susan] and as soon as [the others]1252-the others scattered to hide , [Lucy]60-lucy went to [the room where the wardrobe was]239-the room where the wardrobe was . [She]60-lucy did not mean to hide in the wardrobe , because [she]60-lucy knew that would only set [the others]1252-the others talking again about the whole wretched business . But [she]60-lucy did want to have one more look inside it ; for by this time [she]60-lucy was beginning to wonder [herself]60-lucy whether [Narnia]7-narnia and [the Faun]47-the faun had not been a dream . [The house]1228-the house was so large and complicated and full of hiding places that [she]60-lucy thought [she]60-lucy would have time to have one look into the wardrobe and then hide somewhere else . But as soon as [she]60-lucy reached [it]1228-the house [she]60-lucy heard steps in [the passage]223-the passage outside , and then there was nothing for it but to jump into the wardrobe and hold the door closed behind [her]60-lucy . [She]60-lucy did not shut it properly because [she]60-lucy knew that it is very silly to shut [oneself]243-oneself into a wardrobe , even if it is not a magic one .

Now the steps [she]60-lucy had heard were those of [Edmund]36-edmund ; and [he]36-edmund came into [the room]165-the room just in time to see [Lucy]60-lucy vanishing into [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe . [He]36-edmund at once decided to get into it [himself]36-edmund -- not because [he]36-edmund thought [it]1228-the house [a particularly good place to hide]246-a particularly good place to hide but because [he]36-edmund wanted to go on teasing [her]60-lucy about [[her]60-lucy imaginary country]247-her imaginary country . [He]36-edmund opened the door . There were the coats hanging up as usual , and a smell of mothballs , and darkness and silence , and no sign of [Lucy]60-lucy . " [She]60-lucy thinks [I]36-edmund 'm [Susan]40-susan come to catch [her]60-lucy , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund to [himself]36-edmund , " and so [she]60-lucy 's keeping very quiet in at the back . "[36-edmund] [He]36-edmund jumped in and shut the door , forgetting what a very foolish thing this is to do . Then [he]36-edmund began feeling about for [Lucy]60-lucy in the dark . [He]36-edmund had expected to find [her]60-lucy in a few seconds and was very surprised when [he]36-edmund did not . [He]36-edmund decided to open the door again and let in some light . But [he]36-edmund could not find the door either . [He]36-edmund did n't like this at all and began groping wildly in every direction ; [he]36-edmund even shouted out . " [Lucy]60-lucy ! [Lu]60-lucy ! Where are [you]60-lucy ? [I]36-edmund know [you]60-lucy 're [here]1219-here . "[36-edmund]

There was no answer and [Edmund]36-edmund noticed that [his]36-edmund own voice had a curious sound -- not the sound [you]248-you expect in a cupboard but a kind of open - air sound . [He]36-edmund also noticed that [he]36-edmund was unexpectedly cold ; and then [he]36-edmund saw a light .

" Thank goodness , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , " the door must have swung open of its own accord . "[36-edmund] [He]36-edmund forgot all about [Lucy]60-lucy and went towards the light which [he]36-edmund thought was the open door of [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe . But instead of finding [himself]36-edmund stepping out into [the spare room]1242-the spare room [he]36-edmund found [himself]36-edmund stepping out from the shadow of some thick dark fir trees into an open place in the middle of [a wood]251-a wood .

There was crisp , dry snow under [his]36-edmund feet and more snow lying on the branches of the trees . Overhead there was a pale blue sky , the sort of sky one sees on a fine winter day in the morning . Straight ahead of [him]36-edmund [he]36-edmund saw between the tree trunks the sun , just rising , very red and clear . Everything was perfectly still , as if [he]36-edmund were the only living creature in [that country]252-that country . There was not even a robin or a squirrel among the trees , and the wood stretched as far as [he]36-edmund could see in every direction . [He]36-edmund shivered .

[He]36-edmund now remembered that [he]36-edmund had been looking for [Lucy]60-lucy ; and also how unpleasant [he]36-edmund had been to [her]60-lucy about [her]60-lucy " imaginary country "[60-lucy] which now turned out not to have been imaginary at all . [He]36-edmund thought that [she]60-lucy must be somewhere quite close and so [he]36-edmund shouted , " [Lucy]60-lucy ! [Lucy]60-lucy ! [I]36-edmund 'm [here]1219-here too -- [Edmund]36-edmund . "[36-edmund]

There was no answer .

" [She]60-lucy 's angry about all the things [I]36-edmund 've been saying lately , "[36-edmund] thought [Edmund]36-edmund . And though [he]36-edmund did not like to admit that [he]36-edmund had been wrong , [he]36-edmund also did not much like being alone in [this strange , cold , quiet place]253-this strange , cold , quiet place ; so [he]36-edmund shouted again .

" [I]36-edmund say , [Lu]60-lucy ! [I]36-edmund 'm sorry [I]36-edmund did n't believe [you]60-lucy . [I]36-edmund see now [you]60-lucy were right all along . Do come out . Make it [Pax]56-pax . "[36-edmund]

Still there was no answer .

" Just like [a girl]1231-a girl , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund to [himself]36-edmund , " sulking somewhere , and wo n't accept an apology . "[36-edmund] [He]36-edmund looked round [him]36-edmund again and decided [he]36-edmund did not much like [this place]254-this place , and had almost made up [his]36-edmund mind to go [home]1250-home , when [he]36-edmund heard , very far off in the wood , a sound of bells . [He]36-edmund listened and the sound came nearer and nearer and at last there swept into sight a sledge drawn by two reindeer .

The reindeer were about the size of [Shetland ponies]57-shetland ponies and [their]256-their hair was so white that even the snow hardly looked white compared with [them]256-their ; [their]256-their branching horns were gilded and shone like something on fire when the sunrise caught [them]256-their . [Their]256-their harness was of scarlet leather and covered with bells . On [the sledge]257-the sledge , driving the reindeer , sat [a fat dwarf who would have been about three feet high]258-a fat dwarf who would have been about three feet high if [he]258-a fat dwarf who would have been about three feet high had been standing . [He]258-a fat dwarf who would have been about three feet high was dressed in polar bear 's fur and on [his]258-a fat dwarf who would have been about three feet high head [he]258-a fat dwarf who would have been about three feet high wore a red hood with a long gold tassel hanging down from its point ; [his]258-a fat dwarf who would have been about three feet high huge beard covered [his]258-a fat dwarf who would have been about three feet high knees and served [him]258-a fat dwarf who would have been about three feet high instead of a rug . But behind [him]36-edmund , on a much higher seat in the middle of [the sledge]257-the sledge sat [a very different person]260-a very different person -- [a great lady , taller than any woman that [Edmund]36-edmund had ever seen]261-a great lady , taller than any woman that edmund had ever seen . [She]261-a great lady , taller than any woman that edmund had ever seen also was covered in white fur up to [her]261-a great lady , taller than any woman that edmund had ever seen throat and held a long straight golden wand in [her]261-a great lady , taller than any woman that edmund had ever seen right hand and wore a golden crown on [her]261-a great lady , taller than any woman that edmund had ever seen head . [Her]261-a great lady , taller than any woman that edmund had ever seen face was white -- not merely pale , but white like snow or paper or icing sugar , except for [her]261-a great lady , taller than any woman that edmund had ever seen very red mouth . It was a beautiful face in other respects , but proud and cold and stern .

[The sledge]257-the sledge was a fine sight as it came sweeping towards [Edmund]36-edmund with the bells jingling and [the Dwarf]263-the dwarf cracking [his]263-the dwarf whip and the snow flying up on each side of it .

" Stop ! "[264-the lady] said [the Lady]264-the lady , and [the Dwarf]263-the dwarf pulled the reindeer up so sharp that [they]266-they almost sat down . Then [they]266-they recovered [themselves]266-they and stood champing [their]266-they bits and blowing . In the frosty air the breath coming out of [their]266-they nostrils looked like smoke .

" And what , pray , are [you]36-edmund ? "[264-the lady] said [the Lady]264-the lady , looking hard at [Edmund]36-edmund .

" [I'm]36-edmund -- [I'm]36-edmund -- [my]36-edmund name 's [Edmund]36-edmund , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund rather awkwardly . [He]36-edmund did not like the way [she]264-the lady looked at [him]36-edmund .

[The Lady]264-the lady frowned . " Is that how [you]36-edmund address [a Queen]1299-a queen ? "[264-the lady] [she]264-the lady asked , looking sterner than ever .

" [I]36-edmund beg [your]1299-a queen pardon , [[your]1299-a queen Majesty]1300-your majesty , [I]36-edmund did n't know , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund .

" Not know [the Queen of [Narnia]7-narnia]1301-the queen of narnia ? "[264-the lady] cried [she]264-the lady . " Ha ! [You]36-edmund shall know [us]1302-us better hereafter . But [I]264-the lady repeat -- what are [you]36-edmund ? "[264-the lady]

" Please , [[your]1299-a queen Majesty]1300-your majesty , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , " [I]36-edmund do n't know what [you]1300-your majesty mean . [I]36-edmund 'm at [school]1304-school -- at least [I]36-edmund was -- it 's the holidays now . "[36-edmund]

CHAPTER IV

_ Turkish Delight _

" But what are [you]36-edmund ? "[269-the queen] said [the Queen]269-the queen again . " Are [you]36-edmund [a great overgrown dwarf that has cut off [its]1305-a great overgrown dwarf that has cut off its beard . " " no , your majesty beard . "[269-the queen]

" No , [[your]1299-a queen Majesty]1300-your majesty]1305-a great overgrown dwarf that has cut off its beard . " " no , your majesty , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , " [I]36-edmund never had a beard , [I]36-edmund 'm [a boy]1307-a boy . "[36-edmund]

" [A boy]1307-a boy ! "[269-the queen] said [she]269-the queen . " Do [you]36-edmund mean [you]36-edmund are [a Son of [Adam]48-adam]1234-a son of adam ? "[269-the queen]

[Edmund]36-edmund stood still , saying nothing . [He]36-edmund was too confused by this time to understand what the question meant .

" [I]269-the queen see [you]36-edmund are [an idiot]1310-an idiot , whatever else [you]36-edmund may be , "[269-the queen] said [the Queen]269-the queen . " Answer [me]269-the queen , once and for all , or [I]269-the queen shall lose [my]269-the queen patience . Are [you]36-edmund human ? "[269-the queen]

" Yes , [[your]269-the queen Majesty]1300-your majesty , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund .

" And how , pray , did [you]1300-your majesty come to enter [[my]269-the queen dominions]1312-my dominions ? "[269-the queen]

" Please , [[your]269-the queen Majesty]1300-your majesty , [I]269-the queen came in through a wardrobe . "[269-the queen]

" [A wardrobe]175-a wardrobe ? What do [you]1300-your majesty mean ? "[269-the queen]

" [I]36-edmund -- [I]36-edmund opened a door and just found [myself]36-edmund here , [[your]269-the queen Majesty]1300-your majesty , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund .

" Ha ! "[269-the queen] said [the Queen]269-the queen , speaking more to [herself]269-the queen than to [him]36-edmund . " A door . A door from the world of [men]1316-men ! [I]269-the queen have heard of such things . This may wreck all . But [he]36-edmund is only one , and [he]36-edmund is easily dealt with . "[269-the queen] As [she]269-the queen spoke these words [she]269-the queen rose from [her]269-the queen seat and looked [Edmund]36-edmund full in the face , [her]269-the queen eyes flaming ; at the same moment [she]269-the queen raised [her]269-the queen wand . [Edmund]36-edmund felt sure that [she]269-the queen was going to do something dreadful but [he]36-edmund seemed unable to move . Then , just as [he]36-edmund gave [himself]36-edmund up for lost , [she]269-the queen appeared to change [her]269-the queen mind .

" [[My]269-the queen poor child]1317-my poor child , "[269-the queen] [she]269-the queen said in quite a different voice , " how cold [you]1317-my poor child look ! Come and sit with [me]269-the queen here on the sledge and [I]269-the queen will put [my]269-the queen mantle around [you]1317-my poor child and [we]1318-we will talk . "[269-the queen]

[Edmund]36-edmund did not like this arrangement at all but [he]36-edmund dared not disobey ; [he]36-edmund stepped on to the sledge and sat at [her]269-the queen feet , and [she]269-the queen put a fold of [her]269-the queen fur mantle around [him]36-edmund and tucked it well in .

" Perhaps something hot to drink ? "[269-the queen] said [the Queen]269-the queen . " Should [you]36-edmund like that ? "[269-the queen]

" Yes please , [[your]269-the queen Majesty]1300-your majesty , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , whose teeth were chattering .

[The Queen]269-the queen took from somewhere among [her]269-the queen wrappings a very small bottle which looked as if it were made of copper . Then , holding out [her]269-the queen arm , [she]269-the queen let one drop fall from it on to the snow beside the sledge . [Edmund]36-edmund saw the drop for a second in mid - air , shining like a diamond . But the moment it touched the snow there was a hissing sound and there stood a jewelled cup full of something that steamed . [The Dwarf]263-the dwarf immediately took this and handed it to [Edmund]36-edmund with a bow and a smile ; not a very nice smile . [Edmund]36-edmund felt much better as [he]36-edmund began to sip the hot drink . It was something [he]36-edmund had never tasted before , very sweet and foamy and creamy , and it warmed [him]36-edmund right down to [his]36-edmund toes .

" It is dull , [Son of Adam]1320-son of adam , to drink without eating , "[269-the queen] said [the Queen]269-the queen presently . " What would [you]36-edmund like best to eat ? "[269-the queen]

" Turkish Delight , please , [[your]269-the queen Majesty]1300-your majesty , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund .

[The Queen]269-the queen let another drop fall from [her]269-the queen bottle on to the snow , and instantly there appeared a round box , tied with green silk ribbon , which , when opened , turned out to contain several pounds of the best Turkish Delight . Each piece was sweet and light to the very centre and [Edmund]36-edmund had never tasted anything more delicious . [He]36-edmund was quite warm now , and very comfortable .

While [he]36-edmund was eating [the Queen]269-the queen kept asking [him]36-edmund questions . At first [Edmund]36-edmund tried to remember that it is rude to speak with one 's mouth full , but soon [he]36-edmund forgot about this and thought only of trying to shovel down as much Turkish Delight as [he]36-edmund could , and the more [he]36-edmund ate the more [he]36-edmund wanted to eat , and [he]36-edmund never asked [himself]36-edmund why [the Queen]269-the queen should be so inquisitive . [She]269-the queen got [him]36-edmund to tell [her]269-the queen that [he]36-edmund had [one brother]279-one brother and [two sisters]280-two sisters , and that one of [[his]36-edmund sisters]281-his sisters had already been in [Narnia]7-narnia and had met [a Faun]178-a faun [there]283-there , and that [no one except [himself]36-edmund and [[his]36-edmund brother]285-his brother and [[his]36-edmund sisters]281-his sisters knew anything about [Narnia]7-narnia]284-no one except himself and his brother and his sisters knew anything about narnia . [She]269-the queen seemed especially interested in the fact that there were [four of [them]287-four of them]287-four of them , and kept on coming back to it . " [You]36-edmund are sure there are just four of [you]36-edmund ? "[269-the queen] [she]269-the queen asked . " [Two Sons of [Adam]48-adam]1322-two sons of adam and [two Daughters of Eve]1323-two daughters of eve , neither more nor less ? "[269-the queen] and [Edmund]36-edmund , with [his]36-edmund mouth full of Turkish Delight , kept on saying , " Yes , [I]36-edmund told [you]269-the queen that before , "[36-edmund] and forgetting to call [her]269-the queen " [[Your]269-the queen Majesty]1300-your majesty "[269-the queen] but [she]269-the queen did n't seem to mind now .

At last the Turkish Delight was all finished and [Edmund]36-edmund was looking very hard at the empty box and wishing that [she]269-the queen would ask [him]36-edmund whether [he]36-edmund would like some more . Probably [the Queen]269-the queen knew quite well what [he]36-edmund was thinking ; for [she]269-the queen knew , though [Edmund]36-edmund did not , that this was enchanted Turkish Delight and that [anyone who had once tasted it]289-anyone who had once tasted it would want more and more of it , and would even , if [they]289-anyone who had once tasted it were allowed , go on eating it till [they]289-anyone who had once tasted it killed [themselves]289-anyone who had once tasted it . But [she]269-the queen did not offer [him]36-edmund any more . Instead , [she]269-the queen said to [him]36-edmund ,

" [Son of [Adam]48-adam]1320-son of adam , [I]269-the queen should so much like to see [[your]36-edmund brother]1326-your brother and [[your]36-edmund two sisters]1327-your two sisters . Will [you]36-edmund bring [them]1328-them to see [me]269-the queen ? "[269-the queen]

" [I]36-edmund 'll try , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , still looking at the empty box .

" Because , if [you]269-the queen did come again -- bringing [them]1328-them with [you]269-the queen of course -- [I'd]36-edmund be able to give [you]269-the queen some more Turkish Delight . [I]36-edmund ca n't do it now , the magic will only work once . In [[my]36-edmund own house]1329-my own house it would be another matter . "[36-edmund]

" Why ca n't [we]1330-we go to [[your]290-your house]1331-your house now ? "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund . When [he]36-edmund had first got on to the sledge [he]36-edmund had been afraid that [she]290-your might drive away with [him]36-edmund to [some unknown place from which [he]36-edmund would not be able to get back]291-some unknown place from which he would not be able to get back , but [he]36-edmund had forgotten about that fear now .

" It is a lovely place , [[my]269-the queen house]1332-my house , "[269-the queen] said [the Queen]269-the queen . " [I]269-the queen am sure [you]36-edmund would like it . There are [whole rooms full of Turkish Delight]1333-whole rooms full of turkish delight , and what 's more , [I]269-the queen have [no children of [my]269-the queen own]1334-no children of my own . [I]269-the queen want [a nice boy whom [I]269-the queen could bring up as [a Prince]1336-a prince and who would be [King of [Narnia]7-narnia]1337-king of narnia when [I]269-the queen am gone]1335-a nice boy whom i could bring up as a prince and who would be king of narnia when i am gone . While [he]1335-a nice boy whom i could bring up as a prince and who would be king of narnia when i am gone was [Prince]1338-prince [he]1335-a nice boy whom i could bring up as a prince and who would be king of narnia when i am gone would wear a gold crown and eat [Turkish Delight]58-turkish delight all day long ; and [you]36-edmund are much [the cleverest and handsomest young man [I]269-the queen 've ever met]1339-the cleverest and handsomest young man i 've ever met . [I]269-the queen think [I]269-the queen would like to make [you]36-edmund [the Prince]1340-the prince -- some day , when [you]36-edmund bring [the others]1252-the others to visit [me]269-the queen . "[269-the queen]

" Why not now ? "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund . [His]36-edmund face had become very red and [his]36-edmund mouth and fingers were sticky . [He]36-edmund did not look either clever or handsome whatever [the Queen]269-the queen might say .

" Oh , but if [I]269-the queen took [you]36-edmund [there]283-there now , "[269-the queen] said [she]269-the queen , " [I]269-the queen should n't see [[your]36-edmund brother]1326-your brother and [[your]36-edmund sisters]1344-your sisters . [I]269-the queen very much want to know [your]36-edmund charming relations . [You]36-edmund are to be [the Prince]1340-the prince and -- later on -- [the King]1346-the king ; that is understood . " There 's nothing special about _ [them]1352-them _ , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , " and , anyway , [I]36-edmund could always bring [them]1352-them some other time . "[36-edmund]

" But [I]36-edmund do n't even know the way back to [[my]36-edmund own country]1355-my own country , "[36-edmund] pleaded [Edmund]36-edmund .

" That 's easy , "[269-the queen] answered [the Queen]269-the queen . " Do [you]36-edmund see that lamp ? "[269-the queen]

"[269-the queen]

" [I]36-edmund 'll do [my]36-edmund best , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund .

" And , by the way , "[269-the queen] said [the Queen]269-the queen , " [you]36-edmund need n't tell [them]1252-the others about [me]269-the queen . [I]269-the queen am sure that would be best . If [[your]36-edmund sister]1368-your sister has met [one of [the Fauns]50-the fauns]1369-one of the fauns , [she]1368-your sister may have heard strange stories about [me]269-the queen -- nasty stories that might make [her]1368-your sister afraid to come to [me]269-the queen . [Fauns]50-the fauns will say anything , [you]36-edmund know , and now-- "[269-the queen]

" Please , please , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund suddenly , " please could n't [I]36-edmund have just one piece of Turkish Delight to eat on the way [home]1250-home ? "[36-edmund]

" No , no , "[269-the queen] said [the Queen]269-the queen with a laugh , " [you]36-edmund must wait till next time . "[269-the queen] While [she]269-the queen spoke , [she]269-the queen signalled to [the Dwarf]263-the dwarf to drive on , but as [the sledge]257-the sledge swept away out of sight , [the Queen]269-the queen waved to [Edmund]36-edmund calling out , " Next time ! Next time ! Do n't forget . Come soon . "[269-the queen]

[Edmund]36-edmund was still staring after [the sledge]257-the sledge when [he]36-edmund heard [someone]302-someone calling [his]36-edmund own name , and looking round [he]36-edmund saw [Lucy]60-lucy coming towards [him]36-edmund from another part of [the wood]1273-the wood .

" Oh , [Edmund]36-edmund ! "[60-lucy] [she]60-lucy cried . " So [you]36-edmund 've got in too ! Is n't it wonderful , and now-- "[60-lucy]

" All right , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , " [I]36-edmund see [you]60-lucy were right and it is a magic wardrobe after all . [I]36-edmund 'll say [I]36-edmund 'm sorry if [you]60-lucy like . But where on earth have [you]36-edmund been all this time ? [I]36-edmund 've been looking for [you]36-edmund everywhere . "[36-edmund]

" If [I]60-lucy 'd known [you]60-lucy had got in [I]60-lucy 'd have waited for [you]36-edmund , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy who was too happy and excited to notice how snappishly [Edmund]36-edmund spoke or how flushed and strange [his]36-edmund face was . " [I]60-lucy 've been having lunch with [dear Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus , [the Faun]179-the faun , and [he]49-mr. tumnus 's very well and [the White Witch]1261-the white witch has done nothing to [him]49-mr. tumnus for letting [me]60-lucy go , so [he]49-mr. tumnus thinks [she]1261-the white witch ca n't have found out and perhaps everything is going to be all right after all . "[60-lucy]

" [The White Witch]59-the witch ? "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , " who 's [she]59-the witch ? "[36-edmund]

" [She]59-the witch is [a perfectly terrible person]1373-a perfectly terrible person , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy . " [She]59-the witch calls [herself]59-the witch [the Queen of [Narnia]7-narnia]1301-the queen of narnia though [she]59-the witch has no right to be [queen]1375-queen at all , and [all the Fauns]1376-all the fauns and [Dryads]84-dryads and [Naiads]1377-naiads and [dwarfs]1378-dwarfs and animals -- at least [all the good ones]1379-all the good ones -- simply hate [her]59-the witch . And [she]59-the witch can turn [people]1289-people into stone and do all kinds of horrible things . And [she]59-the witch has made a magic so that it is always winter in [Narnia]7-narnia -- always winter , but it never gets to Christmas . And [she]59-the witch drives about on [a sledge]1381-a sledge , drawn by a reindeer , with [her]59-the witch wand in [her]59-the witch hand and a crown on [her]59-the witch head . "[60-lucy]

[Edmund]36-edmund was already feeling uncomfortable from having eaten too many sweets , and when [he]36-edmund heard that [the Lady [he]36-edmund had made [friends]305-friends with]304-the lady he had made friends with was [a dangerous witch]306-a dangerous witch [he]36-edmund felt even more uncomfortable . But [he]36-edmund still wanted to taste that Turkish Delight again more than [he]36-edmund wanted anything else .

" Who told [you]60-lucy all that stuff about [the White Witch]1261-the white witch ? "[36-edmund] [he]36-edmund asked .

" [Mr. Tumnus]49-mr. tumnus , [the Faun]47-the faun , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy .

" [You]60-lucy ca n't always believe what [Fauns]50-the fauns say , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , trying to sound as if [he]36-edmund knew far more about [them]307-them than [Lucy]60-lucy .

" Who said so ? "[60-lucy] asked [Lucy]60-lucy .

" [Everyone]153-everyone knows it , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , " ask anybody [you]60-lucy like . But it 's pretty poor sport standing here in the snow . Let 's go [home]1250-home . "[36-edmund]

" Yes , let 's , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy . " Oh [Edmund]36-edmund , [I]60-lucy _ am _ glad [you]36-edmund 've got in too . [The others]1252-the others will have to believe in [Narnia]7-narnia now that both of [us]1386-us have been [there]283-there . What fun it will be . "[60-lucy]

But [Edmund]36-edmund secretly thought that it would not be as good fun for [him]36-edmund as for [her]60-lucy . [He]36-edmund would have to admit that [Lucy]60-lucy had been right , before [all the others]308-all the others , and [he]36-edmund felt sure [the others]1252-the others would all be on the side of [the Fauns]50-the fauns and the animals ; but [he]36-edmund was already more than half on the side of [the Witch]59-the witch . [He]36-edmund did not know what [he]36-edmund would say , or how [he]36-edmund would keep [his]36-edmund secret once [they]310-they were all talking about [Narnia]7-narnia .

By this time [they]310-they had walked a good way . Then suddenly [they]310-they felt coats around [them]310-they instead of branches and next moment [they]310-they were both standing outside the wardrobe in [the empty room]224-the empty room .

" [I]60-lucy say , "[60-lucy] said [Lucy]60-lucy , " [you]36-edmund do look awful , [Edmund]36-edmund . Do n't [you]36-edmund feel well ? "[60-lucy]

" [I]36-edmund 'm all right , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , but this was not true . [He]36-edmund was feeling very sick .

CHAPTER V

_ Back on [This Side of the Door _]312-this side of the door _

Because the game of hide - and - seek was still going on , it took [Edmund]36-edmund and [Lucy]60-lucy some time to find [the others]1252-the others . But when at last [they]310-they were all together ( which happened in [the long room]314-the long room , where the suit of armour was ) [Lucy]60-lucy burst out ,

" [Peter]38-peter ! [Susan]40-susan ! It 's all true . [Edmund]36-edmund has seen it too . There is [a country [you]38-peter can get to through the wardrobe]1389-a country you can get to through the wardrobe . [Edmund]36-edmund and [I]60-lucy both got in . [We]315-we met [one another]186-one another in there , in the wood . Go on , [Edmund]36-edmund ; tell [them]1391-them all about it . "[60-lucy]

" What 's all this about , [Ed]36-edmund ? "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter .

And now [we]315-we come to one of the nastiest things in this story . Up to that moment [Edmund]36-edmund had been feeling sick , and sulky , and annoyed with [Lucy]60-lucy for being right , but [he]36-edmund had n't made up [his]36-edmund mind what to do . When [Peter]38-peter suddenly asked [him]36-edmund the question [he]36-edmund decided all at once to do the meanest and most spiteful thing [he]36-edmund could think of . [He]36-edmund decided to let [Lucy]60-lucy down .

" Tell [us]315-we , [Ed]36-edmund , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan .

And [Edmund]36-edmund gave a very superior look as if [he]36-edmund were far older than [Lucy]60-lucy ( there was really only a year 's difference ) and then a little snigger and said , " Oh , yes , [Lucy]60-lucy and [I]36-edmund have been playing -- pretending that all [her]60-lucy story about a country in the wardrobe is true . Just for fun , of course . There 's nothing there really . "[36-edmund]

[Poor Lucy]60-lucy gave [Edmund]36-edmund one look and rushed out of [the room]165-the room .

[Edmund]36-edmund , who was becoming [a nastier person]317-a nastier person every minute , thought that [he]36-edmund had scored a great success , and went on at once to say , " There [she]60-lucy goes again . What 's the matter with [her]60-lucy ? That 's the worst of [young kids]1392-young kids , [they]1392-young kids always-- "[36-edmund]

" Look here , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter turning on [him]36-edmund savagely , " shut up ! [You]36-edmund 've been perfectly beastly to [Lu]60-lucy ever since [she]60-lucy started this nonsense about the wardrobe and now [you]36-edmund go playing games with [her]60-lucy about it and setting [her]60-lucy off again . [I]38-peter believe [you]36-edmund did it simply out of spite . "[38-peter]

" But it 's all nonsense , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund , very taken aback .

" Of course it 's all nonsense , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter , " that 's just the point . [Lu]60-lucy was perfectly all right when [we]1393-we left [home]1250-home , but since [we]1393-we 've been down [here]1219-here [she]60-lucy seems to be either going queer in the head or else turning into [a most frightful liar]1396-a most frightful liar . But whichever it is , what good do [you]36-edmund think [you]36-edmund 'll do by jeering and nagging at [her]60-lucy one day and encouraging [her]60-lucy the next ? "[38-peter]

" [I]36-edmund thought -- [I]36-edmund thought , "[36-edmund] said [Edmund]36-edmund ; but [he]36-edmund could n't think of anything to say .

" [You]36-edmund did n't think anything at all , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter , " it 's just spite . [You]36-edmund 've always liked being beastly to anyone smaller than [yourself]36-edmund ; [we]318-they 've seen that at [school]1304-school before now . "[38-peter]

" Do stop it , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan ; " it wo n't make things any better having a row between [[you]36-edmund two]1398-you two . Let 's go and find [Lucy]60-lucy . "[40-susan]

It was not surprising that when [they]318-they found [Lucy]60-lucy , a good deal later , [everyone]153-everyone could see that [she]60-lucy had been crying . Nothing [they]318-they could say to [her]60-lucy made any difference . [She]40-susan stuck to [her]40-susan story and said :

" [I]40-susan do n't care what [you]36-edmund think , and [I]40-susan do n't care what [you]36-edmund say . [You]36-edmund can tell [the Professor]136-the professor or [you]36-edmund can write to [Mother]61-mother or [you]36-edmund can do anything [you]36-edmund like . [I]40-susan know [I]40-susan 've met [a Faun]178-a faun in there and -- [I]40-susan wish [I]40-susan 'd stayed [there]283-there and [you]36-edmund are all beasts , beasts . "[40-susan]

It was an unpleasant evening . [Lucy]60-lucy was miserable and [Edmund]36-edmund was beginning to feel that [his]36-edmund plan was n't working as well as [he]36-edmund had expected . [The two older ones]320-the two older ones were really beginning to think that [Lucy]60-lucy was out of [her]60-lucy mind . [They]320-the two older ones stood in [the passage]223-the passage talking about it in whispers long after [she]60-lucy had gone to bed .

The result was that next morning [they]320-the two older ones decided that [they]320-the two older ones really would go and tell the whole thing to [the Professor]136-the professor . " [He]136-the professor 'll write to [Father]62-father christmas if [he]136-the professor thinks there is really something wrong with [Lu]60-lucy , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter ; " it 's getting beyond [us]320-the two older ones . "[38-peter] So [they]320-the two older ones went and knocked at [the study]323-the study door , and [the Professor]136-the professor said " Come in , "[136-the professor] and got up and found chairs for [them]320-the two older ones and said [he]136-the professor was quite at [their]320-the two older ones disposal . Then [he]136-the professor sat listening to [them]320-the two older ones with the tips of [his]136-the professor fingers pressed together and never interrupting , till [they]320-the two older ones had finished the whole story . After that [he]136-the professor said nothing for quite a long time . Then [he]136-the professor cleared [his]136-the professor throat and said the last thing either of [them]320-the two older ones expected .

" How do [you]40-susan know ? "[136-the professor] [he]136-the professor asked , " that [[your]40-susan sister]1368-your sister 's story is not true ? "[136-the professor]

" Oh , but-- "[40-susan] began [Susan]40-susan , and then stopped . [Anyone]325-anyone could see from [the old man]326-the old man 's face that [he]326-the old man was perfectly serious . Then [Susan]40-susan pulled [herself]40-susan together and said , " But [Edmund]36-edmund said [they]320-the two older ones had only been pretending . "[40-susan]

" That is a point , "[136-the professor] said [the Professor]136-the professor , " which certainly deserves consideration ; very careful consideration . For instance -- if [you]40-susan will excuse [me]136-the professor for asking the question -- does [your]40-susan experience lead [you]40-susan to regard [[your]40-susan brother]1326-your brother or [[your]40-susan sister]1368-your sister as the more reliable ? [I]136-the professor mean , which is the more truthful ? "[136-the professor]

" That 's just the funny thing about it , [Sir]1405-sir , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter . " Up till now , [I]38-peter 'd have said [Lucy]60-lucy every time . "[38-peter]

" And what do [you]40-susan think , [[my]136-the professor dear]1406-my dear ? "[136-the professor] said [the Professor]136-the professor , turning to [Susan]40-susan .

" Well , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan , " in general , [I]40-susan 'd say the same as [Peter]38-peter , but this could n't be true -- all this about the wood and [the Faun]47-the faun . "[40-susan]

" That is more than [I]136-the professor know , "[136-the professor] said [the Professor]136-the professor , " and a charge of lying against someone whom [you]40-susan have always found truthful is a very serious thing ; a very serious thing indeed . "[136-the professor]

" [We]1407-we were afraid it might n't even be lying , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan . " [We]1407-we thought there might be something wrong with [Lucy]60-lucy . "[40-susan]

" Madness , [you]40-susan mean ? "[136-the professor] said [the Professor]136-the professor quite coolly . " Oh , [you]40-susan can make [your]40-susan minds easy about that . [One]1408-one has only to look at [her]60-lucy and talk to [her]60-lucy to see that [she]60-lucy is not mad . "[136-the professor]

" But then , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan and stopped . [She]40-susan had never dreamed that [a grown - up]331-a grown - up would talk like [the Professor]136-the professor and did n't know what to think .

" Logic ! "[136-the professor] said [the Professor]136-the professor half to [himself]136-the professor . " Why do n't [they]1409-they teach logic at [these schools]1410-these schools ? There are only three possibilities . Either [[your]40-susan sister]1368-your sister is telling lies , or [she]1368-your sister is mad , or [she]1368-your sister is telling the truth . [You]40-susan know [she]1368-your sister does n't tell lies and it is obvious that [she]1368-your sister is not mad . For the moment then and unless any further evidence turns up , [we]334-we must assume that [she]1368-your sister is telling the truth . "[136-the professor]

[Susan]40-susan looked at [him]136-the professor very hard and was quite sure from the expression on [his]136-the professor face that [he]136-the professor was not making fun of [them]334-we .

" But how could it be true , [Sir]1405-sir ? "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter .

" Why do [you]136-the professor say that ? "[136-the professor] asked [the Professor]136-the professor .

" Well , for one thing , "[38-peter] said [Peter]38-peter , " if it was real why does n't [everyone]153-everyone find [this country]1414-this country every time [they]153-everyone go to [the wardrobe]166-the wardrobe ? [I]38-peter mean , there was nothing there when [we]334-we looked ; even [Lucy]60-lucy did n't pretend there was . "[38-peter]

" What has that to do with it ? "[136-the professor] said [the Professor]136-the professor .

" Well , [Sir]1405-sir , if things are real , they 're there all the time . "[38-peter]

" Are [they]334-we ? "[136-the professor] said [the Professor]136-the professor ; and [Peter]38-peter did not know quite what to say .

" But there was no time , "[40-susan] said [Susan]40-susan , " [Lucy]60-lucy had had no time to have gone anywhere , even if there was such a place . [She]60-lucy came running after [us]334-we the very moment [we]334-we were out of [the room]165-the room . It was less than a minute , and [she]60-lucy pretended to have been away for hours . "[40-susan]

" That is the very thing that makes [her]60-lucy story so likely to be true , "[136-the professor] said [the Professor]136-the professor . " If there really is a door in [this house]1418-this house that leads to [some other world]1419-some other world ( and [I]136-the professor should warn [you]40-susan that this is [a very strange house]1420-a very strange house , and even [I]136-the professor know very little about it)--if , [I]136-the professor say , [she]60-lucy had got into [another world]1421-another world , [I]136-the professor should not be at all surprised to find that [that other world]1422-that other world had a separate time of [its]1422-that other world own ; so that however long [you]40-susan stayed there it would never take up any of [our]334-we time . On the other hand , [I]136-the professor do n't think [many girls of [her]60-lucy age]1423-many girls of her age would invent that idea for [themselves]1423-many girls of her age .
